summary: the current study was designed to rigorously measure the reliability of a phylogenetic marker included in segment B. this marker can facilitate molecular epidemiology studies to better explain the links between emergence, spreading and maintenance of the very virulent IBD virus. infectious bursal disease (IBD) is a viral infection that was described for the first time in the 60’s in Gumboro, Delaware, United States. the most important lesions observed in affected animals are lymphoid tissue damage found in the bursa of Fabricius [2]. phylogenetic analyses have revealed independent evolutionary histories for the two genome segments (A and B), suggesting that a reassortment event may have played a role in the emergence of vvIBDV [14]. most of the phylogenetic studies based on segment A use the hyper-variable region of VP2 as phylogenetic marker [18,19,20], whereas those few studies including segment B use the complete segment [21,22]. the presence of a novel IBDV natural reassortant between segments A and B was reported. the present work highlights the need to obtain information about the genetic structure of both genome segments of IBDV, to elucidate the causes of the emergence and spreading. RNA of all 42 samples was extracted from FTA cards using the method described by Moscoso et al. [282] with modifications. RNA was extracted from 150 L of supernatant recovered using Nucleospin RNA virus kit (Macherey-Nagel, Düren, Germany) the resulting products were submitted to bi-directional DNA sequencing using a BigDye Terminator v3.1 cycle sequencing kit. a consensus sequence for each gene was generated using the ChromasPro V1.5 program. sequences were submitted to the GenBank Database under accession numbers. the alignments of the sequences were performed using the algorithm ClustalW method included in the program BioEdit Sequence Alignment Editor [31].
